Land use changes and forestry also play a role by altering the amount of greenhouse gases captured or released by carbon sinks

content.value: The socio-economic and geographical context of Latin America and the Caribbean
Latin America and the Caribbean (hereafter “LAC”) is a heterogenous region spanning approximately 20 million square kilometres (km

. It covers two hemispheres, three oceans (Pacific, Atlantic, Antarctic) and a multitude of ecosystems. Economic development and social wellbeing in LAC are inextricably linked to the natural environment and the quality of the ecosystem services it provides.
LAC is composed of 48 separate administrative units including 33 independent countries and 15 dependent territories with a range of governance arrangements and political systems.

The region has a diverse economy, but most activities are focused on the use and processing of natural resources and their derived products. The GDP of the LAC region represents about 5% of the global economy, i.e. over 5 trillion USD (current prices) in 2021
Portal of inequalities in Latin America: Income distribution

Agriculture is the main economic and social activity thanks to fertile soils and mild climates. Cash crops include coffee and cacao, as well as industrial crops such as corn, soya and wheat. Grazing animals such a sheep, llamas, alpacas, and vicuñas are bred for their meat and their wool used in high quality textiles exported worldwide. The Pampa’s vast pastures feed South America’s livestock. Fisheries are the main economic activity along LAC’s Pacific coast, leading to overfishing and the depletion of many fish populations. Agriculture plays a major role in people’s life, with over 15 million smallholder farms in LAC. About 20‑30% of the workforce in the Caribbean is associated with agricultural activities
Statistical Databases and Publications Ecosystems Surface area of Ramsar designated wetlands
. Forestry is a major economic activity of the Amazon River basin.

Manufacturing industries such as automotive and electronics (for example, large-scale solar panels and television sets), play a key role in larger countries such as Brazil and Mexico – the former having a significant maquila industry associated with the North American Free Trade Agreement. The mining and energy industry is one of LAC’s most important sectors, as the region is endowed in valuable minerals and significant oil and natural gas deposits.
The region’s economic activities have important environmental impacts, but the region is also very vulnerable to global environmental changes that entail risks to its future economic development. .
Real GDP, constant 2015 USD PPP prices

The Gross Domestic Product per capita (USD/person) is expressed at constant 2015 USD PPP prices. GDP per capita measures a country’s economic wealth of the population of a nation. However, as a mean value it does not reflect income distribution. Moreover, it is a 'gross' measure of income and no account is taken of the depreciation neither of produced assets nor of the depletion of natural assets.
Source: OECD, "Green growth indicators", OECD Environment Statistics (database),
The LAC region has 660 million inhabitants, representing approximately 8.3% of global population. Inhabitants are mainly of European, African, Asian and Indigenous descent
Atlas sociolingüistico de pueblos indígenas en América Latina

. The region has a very diverse cultural heritage and ethnic composition. Indigenous populations, while of great variety, contribute to shared understandings, especially with respect to nature and biodiversity, and give the region a unique cultural identity.

The population is predominantly urban (81% in 2020), although there are some differences across the three sub-regions – South America, Central America, and the Caribbean. South America has the highest share (85%), followed by Central America (75%) and the Caribbean (67%). Countries such as Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, Uruguay, Brazil, Mexico and Peru have the highest urban population in the region and even the world
Vulnerability index to climate change in the Latin American and Caribbean Region
. The Caribbean has the highest population density with an average 300 inhabitants per km
in 2021, followed by Central America (106 inhabitants per km
) and South America (25 inhabitants per km

The LAC region is characterised by high levels of income inequality, urban-rural spatial disparities and unequal access to health and infrastructure. Income inequality quantified by the Gini coefficient is around 0.4 (2021 data). However, there are considerable differences across countries; in 2021, the Gini coefficient ranged from 0.395 in the Dominican Republic and 0.402 in Uruguay, to 0.528 in Colombia and 0.537 in Brazil
Life expectancy at birth, by sex

Poverty is a major issue, in particular for urban populations. In 2021, about 32% of the population in urban areas lived in extreme poverty. This share decreases to 13% in rural areas in the same year
Public debt stock as a percentage of GDP
. While this gap has narrowed since the beginning of the millennium, progress has stagnated in the past decade and the economic crisis following the pandemic has aggravated the situation.

The region has been significantly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, experiencing one of the highest mortality rates in the world. Brazil, Peru, and Ecuador were especially affected with high mortality rates and considerable economic and social impacts. This has shown vulnerabilities and difficulties for managing the health and economic crises stemming from the pandemic, as the region experienced the biggest decline in life expectancy at birth (Latin America and the Caribbean lost 2.9 years of life expectancy at birth between 2019 and 2021)
Special Report: Global Warming of 1.5 ºC
These conditions, as well as high public debt across the region – on average 65% of GDP in 2020 and over a 100% in some countries

– limit the capacity to deal effectively with the impacts of climate change. Given the close relationship between economic subsistence and environmental conditions, large groups of the population are likely to be very vulnerable to changes in the global and local environment,.
Source: OECD, "Green growth indicators", OECD Environment Statistics (database),

The region boasts a wide range of climatic features, including close to 4 million hectares of permanent snow and glaciers, over 4 million hectares of mangroves, and over 70 million hectares of Ramsar-designated wetlands
Public debt stock as a percentage of GDP

. The significant climatic variability of the region is, in large part, due to differences in elevation, from lowlands in Mexico and Brazil, to Andean peaks just under 7 000 metres, as well as due to the impact of warm currents from the Atlantic Ocean and cold currents from the Pacific Ocean.

The LAC region is home to the world’s largest river, the Amazon, and the driest desert, the Atacama, with climatic conditions ranging from tropical, to temperate, to arid. This varied physical geography facilitates a range of biomes, making the region the home of the largest biological diversity in the world.

Latin America is home to 23% of the world’s forests, including the Amazon, the world’s largest rain forest which is shared by eight countries. Between 1990 and 2020, the proportion of regional forest cover decreased from 53% to 46% of the territory
Public debt stock as a percentage of GDP

. While most LAC countries suffered a significant net loss, Chile and Costa Rica increased their forest area between 2000 and 2020. After a long period of forest loss last century, Costa Rica implemented recovery and reforestation policies and has managed to increase forest cover replacing land previously used for farming and livestock activities
The economics of climate change in Latin America and the Caribbean
, forests now reaching almost 60% of the country’s total land area (

). In Chile, with around 25% of forest areas, massive exploitation of primary forests and extensive agricultural areas in places with high rainfall were eroding volcanic soils generating problems of stability and water quality

. Policies implemented since 2015 focus on the conservation of natural forests and have encouraged large forest companies to take action in rural development and funding fire prevention which has translated into the recovery of forest land. South America has the largest forest cover, averaging 49% of total land area in 2020

. This is driven by countries such as Suriname, Guyana, Brazil, Peru, Colombia, Venezuela and Ecuador, where more than half of land area is covered by forests. Central America presented an average of 45.6% of forest area and the Caribbean 40% (

Arable and cropland area cover on average 16% of total land area in the Caribbean, 15.5% in Central America and 6.5% in South America. Agriculture provides on average 7% of value added to LAC economies, baring greater importance in Central America, and lesser in South America

. The region contains around 650 million hectares of agricultural area, including meadows and pastures, arable land and permanent crops, of which Brazil counts with the largest, (X%). Countries with high proportions of agricultural area under organic agriculture relative to the region include Uruguay (19% in 2020), French Guiana (11%), Dominican Republic (5%) and Argentina (4%). Land use policies will need to take into account the central role agricultural systems to the LAC economies and societies, representing an important source of income, employment and food for the region and the world
